Fields.DialogueText: Lieutenant, have you seen Sheffield? She disappeared after we left the port.
I'm coming, Captain! I'll be there in a jiffy! I just have to get down the...
*CRASH*
... stairs.
Are... you all right?
I've never been better, Captain! Finally out of port, shiny, shipshape, and armed to the teeth, ready to win any game the Morganas care to throw at us...
There's no better way for a Belle and her ship to be!
You took quite a tumble down those stairs. Are those... roller skates? You weren't wearing those before.
Well, a girl can't exactly wear them around the brass, can she? Not if she's trying to maintain the proper decorum.
But don't you worry, Captain, I'm a pro! I'm training to set the British endurance record!

Fields.MenuText: The... endurance record?
I'm afraid you're going to hurt yourself with those.
I'm afraid you're going to hurt someone with those.

Fields.DialogueText: The longest any United Kingdom citizen has ever roller skated!
Ah, I've had plenty of practice, Captain. I know what I'm doing!
I won't, Captain. I know what I'm doing, and I won't hurt my crew.
You just fell down the stairs.
I slip sometimes, but I'm getting better! Besides, there are advantages to being the lady of this ship. It's not like I could really hurt myself!
I'm made of stronger stuff than your average Belle. Or your average light cruiser. Shinier stuff, too!
Everyone says you're a bit of a strange ship, Sheffield. I'm starting to see just how true that is.
I'm finest the fleet has to offer, Captain. And I'm at your command.
Speaking of which... my radar is picking up aircraft northwest of here. Not friendlies, I think. Probably scouts for some Morgana.
We'll have an opportunity to test our new crew then. Are you ready?
Of course, Captain!
@BATTLE
I'm impressed with the crew so far, Captain. They've kept my decks gleaming.
Hah, well, it's a bit easier to keep you gleaming than the other cruisers. I wouldn't judge them solely on that.
Cleanliness is next to godliness, Captain! And just like any sports team, a ship's crew can't perform well if they don't take proper care of their equipment.
I don't know if I would call a crew a sports team, per se.
War is just another game, Captain. Albeit one with significantly greater consequences than any cup or championship.

Fields.MenuText: Well, when you put it like that...
That's one way to look at it, I suppose.
You shouldn't talk of it so flippantly. Fighting isn't a game.

Fields.DialogueText: It's not the way everyone looks at it, I know. But I find it helpful. It drives up the competitive spirit.
Oh, don't look at me like that, Captain! I know the stakes we're playing for. Calling it a game doesn't mean I take it any less seriously.
Calling it a game doesn't mean I take it any less seriously. I know what we're fighting for, and I don't intend to lose.
This is a game I intend to win. And speaking of winning... my radar's picking up on something unfriendly heading towards us. I doubt she knows we can spot her so far off.
Call the crew to stations. It's time to play your game.
@BATTLE
My radar is picking up a Morgana, about... oh, look! There, on the horizon! You can just see her.
... Well, sort of. Could I borrow your binoculars, Captain?
Of course. Careful with them.
I'm always careful! ... Ah, Morg, you're not in the best of shape, are you? Look at that smoke she's trailing, Captain! I think we're not the first opponent she's matched with today.
... Or she's not good at maintenance. Either way, it's our job to deal with her. I almost feel bad, it's such an uneven match.
Call the crew to stations!
@BATTLE
That... that bitch! She tricked us! She... she... she wasn't playing fair! Pretending to be limping along, just waiting for...
Some overeager cruiser to stumble into her trap?
Damn. Damn! ... What are casualties, Captain? I... I have a vague idea, being a Belle... but I... it's hard to put a number on it.
I haven't received the hard numbers. I don't think they are as bad as they could have been... but they're not good.
... I'm sorry, Captain. I was overconfident. I misjudged her.

Fields.MenuText: We both made mistakes. We'll have to learn from them.
Just don't make the same one again. It costs lives.
Now do you understand this isn't a game?

Fields.DialogueText: We will, Captain. Like they say, fool me once... we can't be fooled like that again.
... I know, Captain. I won't. I... I won't forget this. Not ever.
... It is. It's just one we can't lose, or come close to losing. Not with the price.
... I won't underestimate a Morgana again. They're wicked, and ugly, and cruel... but they're clever too.
What's that you're reading, Sheffield? The Sporting News?
It's an American sports publication, Captain! I like to keep up on baseball news. Football, too. American football, that is...
What's with the sour look?
I just wish the war hadn't ended proper football... English football, that is. My heart belongs to Sheffield United.
The government deemed it too dangerous for people to gather in large groups, so no sports in England ‘til the war's end. If ever.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure football will survive the war.
We'll just have win the war as quickly as possible. For your football.
That's a bit of a trivial thing to be upset about, isn't it?

Fields.DialogueText: If England survives, it will. I'd bet on that! ... So long as England survives.
Ah, don't tease me like that, Captain. I know the reality of it, you've seen me fight. Can't a girl be silly every now and then?
I know, I know, it is. But you and I both know the real cost of war. Can't I be a bit silly and complain about football every now and then?
And sports aren't all trivial, you know. They're about community and bonding.
When big football clubs come together to play, thousands of people turn out to watch them and to engage in healthy competition.
When war takes community away... well, it's one less thing to distract from all the fear. It's one less thing holding people together.
... That does make it sound less trivial.
Hah, but don't listen to me. I'm just sore over not gettin' to watch Sheffield United play. But we're out on the hunt out here, aren't we? And that's a whole other sort of game.
Speaking of... I just picked up a Morgana on my radar. We'd best get the crew to preparations!
@BATTLE
Captain! Lovely weather we're having, isn't it?
If this is your definition of lovely, I'm not sure I want to experience what you would call bad.
Ah, don't say that, Captain! It's just a bit of a storm. Makes staying on course a bit harder, that's all.
... Are you worried, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: Of course not. I've been through worse storms than this, on other ships.
Of course. Our crew isn't experienced handling you yet.
... No. Of course not. Not at all.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad you have experience. That confidence is one of the reasons I chose you to be my Captain. But... it can be unnerving, navigating a storm with a new crew.
That's smart, Captain. A little caution's nothing to be ashamed of! We'll make it through fine, though. Just you wait and see.
Ah, Captain, you don't have to bluster at me. A little caution's nothing to be ashamed of! You've never seen me handle a storm before, after all. But I'll see us through safe.
Trust me, Captain. I'm experienced navigating through these conditions, even if the crew isn't yet. My skills will help them along.
It wouldn't do to let my Captain drown so quickly, would it? I would be the laughingstock of the other Bits!
Don't even joke about that, Sheffield.
Yes, Captain!
... Sheffield.
... Sorry! I'd best concentrate on the ship...
Captain... I'm picking up some aircraft on my radar. Nearby, off to the west.
In this weather?
... There's a Morgana. Trust one of those careless girls to fly her airedales in a storm! What's she thinking?
She's thinking about coming after us, maybe. We can't go after her in this weather... but we should be on the lookout for an attack.
Yes, Captain.
@BATTLE
Captain! Happy about the weather?
I'm happy I can stand on deck without worrying about being swept overboard. Any sign of that Morgana picked up on your radar during the storm?
Not yet... well, actually, I'm just picking something up. She's a few miles from us, Captain.
I picked up a few of her aircraft on my radar... probably scouting for us, or other ships, depending on if she saw us in that storm.
What do you say to giving her a bit of a surprise, Captain?
That should get the crew back into a fighting spirit.
@BATTLE
Hah, you little beauty! What a final hit! I'd say we won that match decisively, Captain.
That Morgana appeared to be in some disorder. We handled her well, but our artillery could have been faster and less sloppy. Especially when we had so much time to prepare.
Sloppy? We'd best run the artillery crews through drills, then. Carelessness is not acceptable aboard the HMS Sheffield.

Fields.MenuText: You're right. We should set more time aside for drilling.
You're a bit of a perfectionist.
Maybe they learned it from you, scrambling around the decks on those roller skates.

Fields.DialogueText: We should. I can organize that with the artillery crews, Captain.
I'm not a perfectionist. I just know drilling and order are important to the proper function of a crew, just like any team.
I'm not careless with my roller skates! I know how to use them! They don't impede my performance in battle, do they?
Organize extra drilling with the artillery crews. We should be faster and better by our next run-in with a Morgana.
Captain! What the bloody hell is going on on my ship?!
What's wrong? ... What happened to your roller skates?
They broke. They broke because I slipped and I slipped because there were puddles of oil on the deck. Puddles!
... Is that why you're all dirty?
Well, if the crew on shift wasn't going to do their job cleaning, someone had to do it! I scrubbed it up and came straight to you.
Messes like that cause unnecessary danger, Captain. Especially when we're at risk of a fight at any time.
... I'll have a word with the officers about who was on maintenance duty and have them reprimanded.
I'll do it.

Fields.MenuText: Very well. Don't be too harsh, though.
I'll take care of it. You've already gone beyond your duty by cleaning up the deck.
Is this about your roller skates?

Fields.DialogueText: I won't. I don't mean to go after anyone. Only to remind them that maintenance, all of it, is life and death out here.
Okay. I guess that's fine. Just remind them it could have been someone more breakable than me, during a battle, who slipped instead.
No, it isn't. I mean... I'm upset they're broken, but I can fix them. It's about the safety and the dignity of this ship.
I'm the lady of the HMS Sheffield, and I and this ship deserve the basic respect of everyone aboard. I'm an expensive piece of technology, you know!
I know. You're one of a kind, Sheffield. I'm sorry about your roller skates.
Ah, I can fix them. ... Oh! Captain. My radar is picking up someone approaching. Not one of ours...
Looks like that talk will have to wait. At least no one will slip on that oil.
I'm glad I cleaned it up before talking to you, but it's the least of our concerns now.
@BATTLE
* ALARM *
Captain, I think I know what is wrong with our crew.
What do you mean? I wasn't aware of anything being wrong with them.
Why they're so careless! Why they don't live up to the standards that they should, serving on a ship of my caliber. Especially the artillery crews.
They're not working as a cohesive unit yet, Captain. There's not the sense of camaraderie that there should be. I mean, we've been through battles together, but it still isn't quite there.
Hmm. I've noticed the crew do tend to divide along the lines of nationality, for the most part...
That's part of the problem, Captain. A big part of it. They're not behaving like a team should.
Well, most naval sailors aren't used to working in multinational crews.
The whole existence of the Protection Fleet is something unique, and it's not surprising that it would take a while for everyone to get used to it.
I know. But divisions like this cause the sort of carelessness I've been complaining about, and they breed dissent.
The crew isn't a proper team yet. They don't even seem to feel ownership or pride in their ship.

Fields.MenuText: What do you think we should do to change that?
I think that sense of pride and team spirit will develop in time.
Is this all about you maintaining your shine?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not sure yet, Captain. Maybe it will develop in time. It should, but these are unusual circumstances. I don't know.
Maybe it will, Captain. But... maybe it won't if we don't push it.
No! This is about the war, Captain. A ship with a careless crew is at risk of losing and being sunk - or worse, making a mistake that damages the war effort as a whole.
I'll speak to my officers about this. For now, we received orders from the fleet to sail north.
There's been multiple sightings of a Morgana off the coast of Ireland and the fleet is worried she might start attacking civilian ships.
My radar's picking up Morgana signals! Maybe a good fight is just what the crew needs.
@BATTLE
I wish there was more time for the traditional navy sports. There's nothing like a bit of friendly competition to bring people together. Alas, wartime.
And a hello to you, too.
Sorry, Captain! I was just musing about our crew. Competition does bring people together, after all. I mean there's the fistfighting, but that's not exactly a team sport...
... Fistfighting?
Don't you know it? It's a traditional pastime for sailors. There's nothing like a bit of a fight to get the blood pumping.
And it's a good source of entertainment, so long as there are rules and someone to stop it from going too far.

Fields.MenuText: I know that. I was just surprised you did.
... Surely that's against regulations.
Fistfighting?!

Fields.DialogueText: I know that! And I know about most things that go on aboard my ship, Captain. That's the life of a Belle.
Well... yes. It's something that officers turn a blind eye to more often than not, though.
Don't look so shocked! It's not like there's a great deal of entertainment aboard a ship. It's good fun, for the most part.
I'm glad some of our crew members have started doing things like this. It shows that camaraderie's developing, at least.
... That's one way to look at it.
Don't worry, Captain. I've made a point to show up to these events. I've made it clear that I'm one for a healthy back and forth, but I'll stop things if they go too far.
Hmm.
Captain, my radar is picking something up to the south. I think it's a few aircraft... scouts for a Morgana, most likely.
We can talk about this later, if you like, but we have bigger fights to worry about now.
Very well. We'll talk later.
@BATTLE
Hello, Captain! Did we receive any new orders?
... What happened to you? Are you all right?
Um... oh! It's just a black eye, Captain! And a few bruises. Nothing to worry about.

Fields.MenuText: Did you slip down the stairs again?
How the hell did you get so banged up?
... What have you been doing?

Fields.DialogueText: No, Captain. Well, I did, but I didn't get these through that. I was...!
I, I, um, you see, Captain, I... wait!
... Well... you see... Captain!
My radar just picked up three aircraft coming towards us. They're probably a Morgana's entourage.
... You're sure?
Yes, Captain! Absolutely.
We'll talk later. Call the crew to stations! Have you picked up the ship yet?
Yes, Captain. She's a Morgana. Definitely.
Time to prepare for a fight, then.
@BATTLE
You've been fighting, haven't you? That's where you got those bruises.
... Yes, Captain.
By the way you're acting, it's obvious you thought I would be displeased. You had that thought, so you went behind my back to participate in fistfights with my crew.
... Our crew, Captain...
Our crew. Why, exactly, were you participating in these fights?
It... because I thought it was healthy for the camaraderie of the ship. It's... it's entertaining, and it was helping the crew grow closer together. I referee, sometimes.
... Occasionally, I participate. It entertained the crew to see a smaller woman like me take on well-muscled sailors. It gave their confidence in their Belle a bit of a boost.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not angry, but I don't think your participation in these fights is appropriate. You're basically an officer, Sheffield.
Regardless of my feelings on you fighting, you shouldn't have tried to conceal something like this from me.
What the hell did you think you were doing? You're a Belle, not a seaman!

Fields.DialogueText: ... I'm not an officer, though. I'm not in the chain of command. I'm not abusing my position this way, nor do I think it's degrading me in the eyes of the crew.
... I didn't think to bring it up to you. I wasn't concealing it on purpose, I just didn't think it was something I needed to tell you. I thought you had enough to deal with as it was.
I'm the lady of this ship! I'm supposed to bring the crew together, and I'm doing what I can to do that, Captain!
*ALARM*
...Clearly this matter has at least distracted you, since you didn't realize a Morgana was inbound.
We can talk about this later.
@BATTLE
Sheffield.
I'm busy, Captain! I'm helping with the...
Sheffield. Stop sulking and come here right now.
... Yes, Captain.
I wasn't sulking, Captain! I was lending a hand.
Just because you sulk industriously doesn't mean it isn't sulking. You've been avoiding me.
... Yes, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not angry at you for participating in the fights. I'm sorry if I spoke too harshly earlier.
I'm sorry if I spoke too harshly before. I don't approve of what you were doing. But I hadn't given you any orders about it, so I can't fault you.
I don't want you fighting anymore. I don't think it's appropriate. But I don't want this rift between us to continue.

Fields.DialogueText: ... I'm sorry, too, Captain. I was being stubborn. Compared to everything else, it's not important, and I shouldn't have made such a fuss.
Ah, it's all good, Captain. I'm sorry for being stubborn. You're my Captain. I should listen to you.
... I'll follow your orders, Captain. I'm sorry for being stubborn. I... I don't want to ruin what's between us.
I'm glad we could clear that up. That being said, I don't want you to participate in any fights for the immediate future.
Why, Captain?
We've received orders to pick up a fleet diplomat in Portsmouth and transport him to Denmark. He has a reputation for being suspicious of Belles, and generally a troublemaker.
... And you don't want to give him any specific reasons to make trouble. I understand, Captain.
I'm glad. I hope to complete this assignment as soon as possible.
@BATTLE
My radar's picking up-
*ALARM*
... Morganas, Captain.
Caaaapptaaaaiiiinnnn!
Sheffield? What...?
*CRASH*
Sorry, Captain! I didn't mean to crash into you! I guess I'm still getting the hang of my roller skates.
... Ouch. Ow.
Captain? Are you okay?

Fields.MenuText: I'm fine, just a bit bruised, I think.
You've killed me.
Be more careful next time!

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, I'm sorry, Captain! I'll be more careful. Here, let me give you a hand.
You look pretty alive to me, Captain. Somehow, I think you'll pull through.
... Sorry, Captain! I will, I promise.
I was just coming to say that I think there's a Morgana hunting us, Captain.
My radar hasn't picked her up... I think she's a long way off... but I keep picking up little blips of aircraft. They're too consistent to be accidental.
Hmm. A fight on a Morgana's terms isn't something we want.
No, Captain. We should take matters into our own hands. From the direction of her aircraft, I think she's to the south of here. Near Gibraltar, maybe.
That alone is reason enough to see if we can hunt her down.
@BATTLE
Sailors - battle stations!
Sheffield! Come meet our guest. Preferably without...
Yes, Captain! I'm coming!
... roller skates. Hello, Sheffield. This is Mr. James Bennett, the diplomat who will be travelling with us for a time.
It's good to meet ya, Mr. Bennett. I'm Sheffield, the Lady of the HMS Sheffield, at your service!
It's a pleasure to make your acquaintance, Lady Sheffield. It's good to see a representative of our own navy so enthusiastic in the service of the Protection Fleet.
It's a pleasure to serve the fleet, Captain! Especially under a captain as fine as mine.
Sheffield, could you perhaps give Mr. Bennett a tour of the ship? I have some business to attend to...
*ALARM*
What's that noise?
It's the alarm. One of the lookouts must have spotted something... yes! I'm picking her up on my radar now. It's a Morgana, Captain. A big one, heading straight for Portsmouth.
Seaman! See Mr. Bennett to his quarters. It looks like you'll get a taste of action after all, Mr. Bennett.
Wonderful. Perhaps I could stay on the bridge with you? I'm quite certain I know how to handle myself.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure, but for safety's sake, you should get to your quarters.
I doubt you've been in the middle of a fight like this. Get to your quarters.
You don't argue with a captain onboard a ship. Get to your quarters!

Fields.DialogueText: It really is for the best, Mr. Bennett.
It can get a bit chaotic up here, Mr. Bennett.
You heard what he said! Follow the seaman, Mr. Bennett.
There'll be time for sightseeing later. For now, we've got a match to win.
A match?
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Captain?
I see them.
@BATTLE
Captain, I know you're busy with the cleanup from that fight, but can I have a word with you?
Sure. What is it, Mr. Bennett?
Captain, I admire the rough and ready look your Belle is going for, I really do.
But I'm a bit concerned it might not carry across quite the right... dignity, for a representative of the United Kingdom.
Might I suggest dressing her in more conservative attire?
Excuse me? Dressing me? What do you think I am, some sort of doll?
Ah, Sheffield! I'm sorry, I didn't see you there...
There's very little that goes on aboard this ship that escapes my eyes and ears, Mr. Bennett.
I would suggest you focus on refining your diplomacy, and keep out of naval business.

Fields.MenuText: You should take Sheffield's advice, Mr. Bennett.
Sheffield, Mr. Bennett is our guest. Mr. Bennett... Sheffield is her own entity. I don't presume to tell her how to dress.
Sheffield, Mr. Bennett is our guest. You will address him with respect... regardless of his actions.

Fields.DialogueText: Yeah, step off. No one asked for your opinion.
... I am the lady of this ship. He has no right to be rude to me, especially when he doesn't have the brass to say it to my face.
I'll give him his due respect when he gives me mine.
My apologies if this topic of conversation caused offence. I'm only concerned with what's in our country's best interests, Sheffield. Good day to you both.
... Who the hell does he think he is?
We were warned. But it would be best not to pick fights with him. We'll have him delivered soon enough.
Hmm. I guess so.
*ALARM*
Good job to whoever spotted that lot. They're a good way out still...
I'll make a note, Captain.
@BATTLE
Captain! Are you all right? Let me give you a hand. Did you hit your head? ... I thought that last hit felt strong enough to shake the ship to bits!
Augh... I'm... fine, I think. I just got knocked down.
... Oh. Ah, good. That's good! For a minute... well, it would have been pretty irritating to have to pick a new captain so soon!

Fields.MenuText: Does that mean you're growing fond of me, Sheffield?
I wasn't aware I had become irreplaceable already, Sheffield.
Good to know I'm convenient to you, Sheffield.

Fields.DialogueText: ... Well, I did pick you, Captain. And I haven't regretted my choice. Not yet, anyway.
Ha! Don't get such an inflated opinion of yourself, Captain. Nobody is irreplaceable. Except me, that is. I'm one of a kind!
Oh, I didn't mean it that way, Captain! I... well... I did choose you. I don't want you to get hurt. ... And it would hurt the war effort, anyway.
Well, I did notice something while I was on the floor. You've added something new to your roller skates.
Oh! Ah, I thought, with the time it took to fix my roller skates, why not take the opportunity to spangle them up a bit? That's the Sheffield United logo!
Hah. I suppose I should be glad you didn't paint it on the side of the ship.
Don't go giving me ideas, Captain.
I'm not normally one to complain about a fight, but I wish the fleet wouldn't send us hunting after Morganas now... I just want to get rid of Mr. Bennett.
Sheffield!
What? I understand he's important to the fleet. We're doing our duty bringing him to Denmark. I just wish we could do our duty quicker.
Well, the Morgana harassing the Scottish coast isn't going to wait for us to drop off Mr. Bennett before attacking someplace like Edinburgh.
I know, I know. Nothing's gonna stop me from doing my duty, Captain. That doesn't mean I have to like it.
You have been more pleased with our crew, I've noticed. And the artillery crews have been performing much better since you've been running drills.
Ah! Thank you, Captain! I'm glad you noticed. I've been motivating them with a bit of healthy competition.
What sort of healthy competition?
Well... maybe I'll answer that question when Mr. Bennett isn't prowling around, eh?

Fields.MenuText: I get your meaning.
That's fair enough.
I get the feeling I won't approve of this...

Fields.DialogueText: Good! Keep it hush-hush for now, Captain.
I promise I'll tell you later, Captain. It's nothing bad; just maybe a little too unladylike for Mr. Bennett's sensibilities.
I don't think you'll mind. It's nothing to do with fistfighting, Captain.
Now we'd best start hunting for the Morg if we're to get rid of Mr. Bennett!
Don't shout that.
@BATTLE
What's put that mournful look on your face, Sheffield?
What? Oh, hello, Captain. Sorry. I didn't hear you walk up beside me. Ah, nothing. I'm just a bit tired, that's all.
Ah. I didn't know that was possible.
Possible for a Belle, or possible for me?
Both? Either. You're an energetic individual... and Belles don't seem to have the same restraints humans do.
Well... we don't like to talk about that one. But it is something of a matter of preference.
... I'm not so much physically tired. My engines don't get tired, do they? I'm just... I miss Sheffield, a little bit. I love the ocean, but the view out here can get a little plain.
No trees, no greenery, no rustling leaves and singing songbirds... just the sea. It's enough to make a girl tired.
You think of Sheffield as your home, then?
Of course. As much as I've got one, at least. There are a lot of trees in Sheffield. Even though I've never seen them with my own eyes, I think that's what I miss the most.
... How about you, Captain? Do you miss home?

Fields.MenuText: I do. I know I'm fighting to protect it, though.
My home is the sea. I'm happy here.
I don't. It's not worth going back to.

Fields.DialogueText: Me, too. That does make me happy. And proud. ... It doesn't stop me from missing the trees, though.
I'm glad. I'm glad to share your home with you, then, for this time.
It's not really your home then, is it? I hope you find a new one.
Hah! My radar just picked up a Morgana. Right on time, to keep us from starting to bawl. Or should I say, to keep you from starting to bawl.
You're the one whose eyes are looking a little teary, Sheffield.
Hmm. ... Come on. We're tough. We have a match to win.
@BATTLE
Captain! Wanna race me to the stern?
Excuse me?
Come on, it'll be fun!

Fields.MenuText: Sure, why not? I could outpace you any day.
With you on your roller skates? That's not exactly fair.
I don't call getting outpaced by you fun.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll make you eat those words, Captain!
Oh, come on! I'll take them off if you really want me to, Captain.
Ah, come on! You're more competition than that, Captain.
Ugh, I'll get you to race me another time. We'll have to call truce for now... there's a Morgana on my radar who wants a match.
Good to know a Morgana takes priority over me.
Well, I'd much rather be on your side than on any Morgana's. Come on, Captain, let's go!
@BATTLE
Captain, could I have a word with you?
Sure. What is it, Mr. Bennett?
I may have been too forward in our last conversation about your Belle, but you must understand I'm only worried about her position as a representative of our country.
I understand. But she is both a member of the fleet and her own person, and you should keep those things in mind when you talk about her.
Yes, I understand that, but... Captain, I've heard some frankly shocking things about her! The crew does talk, you know.
... What have you heard?
I've heard she participates in fistfights with the crew! That she cavorts with them shamelessly! She's reportedly giving out kisses as prizes to the best artillery crews...
Excuse me?! Are you trying to badmouth me to my captain? On my own ship? What sort of useless Belle do you think I am?

Fields.MenuText: She's right. You've continually been disrespectful of Sheffield, Mr. Bennett.
Sheffield, calm down for a moment. Mr. Bennett, stop making wild accusations.
... Is what he's saying true, Sheffield?

Fields.DialogueText: You're our guest, Captain. You should be more respectful of your hosts.
Calm down! He's the one slandering me! He's blowing everything out of proportion!
What? Captain... how... how could you side with him?
*ALARM*
Both of you, be quiet for a minute. That's the alarm. We'll have to settle this later.
But, Captain...
I... Yes, Captain.
@BATTLE
Now tell me, Sheffield, how many of Mr. Bennett's complaints are true?
... I hate him.
I know. I'm not saying he's reasonable.
Well... well you know, I did participate in the fights, sometimes. I stopped when you asked me too, though. He must have heard some gossip from the crew.
He seems to have a keen ear for it. And the part about you cavorting with the crew?
Does that sound like something I would do?

Fields.MenuText: Honestly... yes.
Maybe not openly.
Maybe not?

Fields.DialogueText: Well... you're probably right. But not during a time of war, when we're on duty!
Not on duty, certainly. Not when we're hunting Morganas.
I like to have a good time, sure. But not if I'm neglecting my job doing so. I don't cavort on duty.
I haven't done anything of that nature since the war started.
I believe you.
You do?
Of course. But the bit about the kisses...
Well, I have been drilling the artillery crews, and I...
Captain! There's a Morgana on my radar! She's heading straight for us! She's... an aircraft carrier, I think.
Your radar, saving us from both Morganas and awkward conversations.
Ha... ha.
@BATTLE
Sheffield! I have some news.
What kind of news?
The kind you won't like.
Lay it on me, Captain. Quickly, though. I think there might be a Morgana eyeing us with her aircraft.
We have to make another detour before dropping off Mr. Bennett. To the coast of Norway.
There are several Morgana cruisers who have been sinking merchant ships up and down the coast.
... Really? Why do we keep getting diverted with these kind of missions?
Maybe they want to give your artillery crews more practice.
My crews have been doing wonderfully, and you know it!

Fields.MenuText: Ah, I'm just giving you a hard time. They've improved a lot.
They have been doing better than before.
Really? I hadn't noticed...

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Captain. Nothing but a bit of teamwork and competition!
I'm glad you noticed, Captain. It just takes a little competition to get them to shine.
Then you haven't been paying enough attention to what goes on during our battles, Captain!
It does look like they'll have more opportunities for real practice right now... a Morgana is closing in on us at this moment, Captain.
We'll be ready for her.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I think it's just one this time.
Good. But don't get complacent.
@BATTLE
That cruiser forfeited after just a few minutes!
I can see why she would have been a problem for the local merchants, though.
True. Hmm. Can we get rid of Mr. Bennett now?
Sheffield!
What, do you like him?

Fields.MenuText: Well, no.
No, but he is our responsibility.
He's not so bad. Show a little respect.

Fields.DialogueText: See? I'm just saying what you're thinking. I know you've got to play nice, but I can voice your frustrations for you.
I know, I know. I just want to make him someone else's responsibility as soon as possible.
I'll show him respect when he shows me a little decency.
Anyway, let's set course to Denmark.
Is there any sign of this storm abating, Captain?
Captain...
What? No rude comments for me today?
Captain, there's a Morgana on my radar. She's... she's coming after us. I think she's going to attack.
What? In this storm? That's impossible.

Fields.MenuText: I have faith in this ship and in our crew. We can fight her.
I suppose we have to.
There's no way we can win this.

Fields.DialogueText: That's the spirit, Captain! We can win this!
We have to fight, and we have to win, Captain. That's that.
We can, Captain! We can, and we will.
Did you just call your Captain...
This isn't the time for that, Bennett. You believe you can hold this ship steady through the storm, Sheffield? Steady enough the crew can fight?
Yes, Captain.
And you believe that the crew will be able to fight well?
Yes, Captain.
I believe in you. Let's do this.
@BATTLE
Not so far, I'm afraid. It'll probably die down by morning, but for now, we're just going to have to hold on. You should return to your quarters, Mr. Bennett.
Nobody's told her that, Captain. She's a cruiser, too. We won't be able to outrun her. I... I don't think. We have to fight her.
Were you sad to bid farewell to Mr. Bennett?
Hah. You know... you never did elaborate on those rumours of you kissing members of the artillery crew.
... Ah. Do I have to, Captain?
I'm very curious.
Well, I may have joked about rewarding the best artillery crewmen with kisses once they proved themselves. At the end of this cruise.
It was just a joke, Captain!
It would be... well, it would be inappropriate for me to go around kissing crew members.
Not even after our last victory?
Not even after that. I mean... you're mostly to be thanked for that one, Captain.
And you, and the crews you drilled. I think we all had a hand in it.
Well, I think you'd be the one owed the kiss, if there was to be one.
Tell me, Captain, do you have a sweetheart?
Excuse me?
Do you have someone you hold dear, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: That's none of your business, Sheffield. No offence.
Not right now, no. Why, Sheffield?

Fields.DialogueText: Fair enough. I don't kiss people who might be tied up elsewhere, even if they're my captain. But I certainly am glad I chose you.
Well, if you *are* owed that kiss, you really ought to find a kisser. So to speak.
Hah! You're funny, Captain. But... I do wish him luck in Denmark. He has a job to do, just like us. Even if he's a prat.
